title: How to Read the News: Journalism and Media in an Era of Newsroom Cuts and “Fake News”
yc_attrs: This course can be applied towards the Social Sciences Yale College distributional requirement.
ci_attrs: YC Poli Sci: American Govt
description:
With so many questions about quality, quantity, and bias in today's headlines, individual consumers of news need to be active participants in the news ecosystem. Students are taught journalistic skills and practices that help them make sense of the modern media maelstrom. Students are asked to create and curate their own digital news platform, acting throughout the semester as its editor and collecting clips of what they think are the most important stories of the week. Using class lectures and readings as criteria for analysis, students annotate their weekly selections. By the end of the semester, students develop their own agenda for the editorial, business, or technological changes that need to be made so that journalism can continue to protect humane, democratic society. 

Enrollment limited to first-year students. Preregistration required; see under First-Year Seminar Program.
instructordetail_html: Andrew Butters
